rev.comment: /* Gaia */ It is not really necessary to include an article about a security system that we know nothing about. Maybe it should be mentioned somewhere else.

Also in 2007, Google acquired [[Postini]]<ref>[http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2007/09/weve-officially-acquired-postini.html The Official Google Blog - We've Officially Acquired Postini]</ref> and continued to sell the acquired technology<ref>[http://www.google.com/intl/en/press/pressrel/apps_postini_20071003.html Google Press Center - Google Adds Postini's Security and Compliance Capabilities to Google Apps]</ref> as Google Security Services.<ref>[http://www.google.com/a/help/intl/en/security/index.html Google - Google Security Services]</ref>
â   â
===Gaia===
  â
''Gaia'' is a codename for a security technology employed by Google. Little is known about this technology other than that it is the security behind their single sign-on system that protects their services like Gmail, Docs, Calendar, etc.
  â   â
Gaia was mentioned only once by Google themselves, at a tech conference in 2006. However, it has recently come to light that in the Chinese hacking attempt, they managed to steal the source code for Gaia. Google has since made security enhancements to Gaia, to preemptively counter any flaws found in Gaia by those behind the theft.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/20/technology/20google.html |title=Cyberattacks on Google Said To Hit Password System|first=John|last=Markoff|date= April 19, 2010|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
